Award.AwardTitle: Structure and Catalytic Property Relationship of Core-Shell Metal Nanoparticles
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division Professor Hong Yan of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign will develop new heterogeneous, metallic catalysts as well as fundamental understanding of the structural origins of their high performance in oxygen reduction reactions (ORR) and in chemical conversion of major by-products from biomass. Specifics aims are: 1) study of the preparation and fine nanostructures of M@Pt (core@shell) particle-on-particle heterogeneous nanostructures; 2) study of the structure and catalytic property relationship of M@Pt or M@PtM catalysts in ORR; 3) design, synthesis and ORR catalytic property of faceted heterogeneous Pt multimetallic nanocrystal catalysts; and 4) thermal chemical conversion of glycerol using on Pt-based core-shell heterogeneous catalysts. Preparation, atomic level characterization and structure-catalytic property relation of core-shell, heterogeneous nanostructures will be examined. Effect of particular structural issues such as facet and surface distortion on catalytic performance will be carefully studied.

New production technologies using alternative energy sources, including hydrogen and biofuel, heavily depend on the development of new generation of advanced catalysts to facilitate and accelerate reactions using less energy than conventional systems. This project will directly address this technological challenge through the design and understanding of new bimetallic nanostructures. It will also serve as a training platform for students at all levels and with different social, economic backgrounds to become able scientists to carry out life-long research in the utilization of new sustainable energy sources. The knowledge gained during this work will be rapidly disseminated through scientific publications, conference presentations and web-based media.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under this project, complex bimetallic nanostructures were developed as active catalysts and electrocatalysts for applications as hydrogen fuel cell electrode, and in the conversion of hydrocarbon chemicals.  One major development in catalyst design accomplished is the dynamic control of surface chemical compositions and structures through chemical vapor treatment. Such approach can result in highly selective and active catalysts. Another important discovery is the development of in situ experimental methods for understanding the formation of core-shell particle catalysts at sub-nanometer length scale, allowing for quantitative analysis of the particle growth that has not been possible before.

The result of this project will lead to further advancement of fabrication of precision metal catalysts, which have the proper chemical composition and morphology that are needed to eliminate the unwanted chemicals through enhancing the selectivity of the reactions and/or reduce the cost of chemical process by increasing the ability to rapidly produce useful products per unit time. For instance, this research developed the process for making faceted platinum-nickel fuel cell catalysts that are about an order of magnitude more active than pure platinum commercial catalysts.

To better identify the best catalysts, the PI developed methods for researching metal nanoparticles based on computational models. Such development will aid the future discovery of catalysts for chemical and energy industries.

This project improved the PI's ability to attract students and ensure their stay in STEM professions. Leveraged with other supports, two graduate students were trained in the area of chemical catalysis and went on to become postdoctoral researchers at a national lab. Several undergraduate research interns, including three female students, were able to work in the PI's group. The lab experience helped these students to develop the skills to be competitive. Two became graduate students in the Nation's top public universities.

Over the funding time period, more than a dozen of publications in high impact journals were generated, together with several dozens of invited seminars and public research lectures given. Results were also disseminated to broader audiences via a variety of social media outlets, such as Science 360 and Science Daily.

 


Last Modified: 03/16/2017
Modified by: Hong Yang
